Description.val:
The Advanced Medium Range Air-to-Air Missile (AMRAAM) is the premier all-weather, all-environment radar guided missile developed jointly by the Air Force and Navy.  The Air Force is the lead service.  AMRAAM is a small, light, fast missile with improved capabilities against very low and high-altitude targets in an electronic attack (EA) environment.  The AIM-120D provides increased performance from improved kinematics,  GPS-aided navigation, a two-way data link; which enhances aircrew survivability and network compatibility. Additional enhancements include new guidance software to combat a technologically capable adversary to reduce risk in air combat scenarios, and limit missile defense challenges.

Differences in All Up Round Unit Cost between the Navy and Air Force is the result of the variations in procurement of missile types of each service.

Justification.val:
FY 2021 funding procures 325 AMRAAM missiles in support of warfighter requirements. 

Funding also provides required support costs such as: test and technical production support, procurement of training equipment, diminishing manufacturing sources, and test equipment/test equipment upgrades to support the AIM-120D configuration.

Note: Procurement quantities can change based on negotiated options/pricing bands and available funding, in accordance with Title 10, US Code Section 2308 BUY-TO-BUDGET ACQUISITION

Name.@footnote: Unit cost calculations are based on combined procurement of Navy, Air Force and FMS buys for each fiscal year.  FY20 and FY21 are the first full rate production lots of the Form, Fit, Function Refresh (F3R) missile (AIM-120D-3) which contains newer and more costly components resulting in an increased unit cost.  Unit costs are projected to stabilize in the out years.  FY19 and FY20 AUR quantities decreased as a result of training requirements associated with CATM procurements. Separately, the program anticipated a budget requirement for warranty costs in FY19 and FY20 within this cost category.  These warranty costs were not realized. Therefore, the program intends to use this funding to buy to budget and procure an additional 26 AURs in FY19 and 23 AURs in FY20.

AIM-120 MSR is 400 missiles per year, consisting of USN, USAF, and approved FMS procurement with no less than 100 of a particular variant.  Beginning in FY21, max factory capactity enables production of 1,200 missiles per year.

CATMs - Recent changes to the Warfighter training and employment of the AMRAAM in the NAWDCINST 3500.3, have resulted in an update to the Navy Training Systems Plan which now reflects as an increase in AMRAAM Captive Air Training Missile (CATM)-120D (CATM-120D) requirements.  As a result of these changes, CATMs are being procured in FY2020 and FY2021.
Name.val: 1.1.2) AIM-120 MISSILE - CAPTIVE AIR TRAINING MISSILE (CATM)

Name.@footnote: Engineering Change Orders line provides funding to test and qualify class I engineering change proposals by the prime vendor into missile production.  Fluctuations correspond directly with total cost of hardware procured.

Training equipment request includes funding for AMRAAM Telemetry System (ATS) used to collect missile performance data for in production missiles to support product improvement within the current performance envelope.  FY21 funding increase is due to the ATS requirement for AIM-120D-3 missile procurements.
